Hydrothermally fabricated Yb2O3 catalyst for vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol to isoprene Ryo Kobayashi Writing – original draft Visualization Data curation Enggah Kurniawan Writing – review & editing Takayoshi Hara Validation Data curation Yasuhiro Yamada Validation Supervision Satoshi Sato Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263–8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Chiba 263–8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba, 263–8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Several rare-earth oxides, prepared through a hydrothermal process, were employed as catalysts for vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol (3MBDO) to isoprene. Ytterbium oxide (Yb2O3) emerged as the most efficient catalyst for the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene. The hydrothermal time and calcination temperature influenced the performance of Yb2O3. The reaction temperature and contact time strongly affect the dehydration of 3MBDO and unsaturated alcohols, while the major side reaction of isobutene formation via decomposition of 3-methyl-3-butene-1-ol was mainly influenced by the reaction temperature. The highest isoprene yield of 92% was achieved at 450 °C and a long contact time of 3.75 h. The poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine revealed the importance of base and acid sites of Yb2O3 in the dehydration of 3MBDO, indicating the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene proceeded via an acid-base concerted mechanism. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Ytterbium oxide Hydrothermal 3-Methyl-1,3-butanediol Vapor-phase dehydration Isoprene Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Sustainable and green processes have been boosted to mitigate the environmental impact of the continuous usage of fossil fuels [1–3]. In this regard, the catalytic transformation of abundant and renewable biomass-derived chemicals has emerged as a promising strategy to alleviate the dependency on fossil fuels [3–5]. Nevertheless, the rapidly growing demand for chemicals and energy to supply numerous industries remains the major reason for the high consumption of fossil fuels since fossil fuels are the main resource to supply the backbone chemicals [5]. Therefore, the continuous effort to design efficient catalytic systems for biomass valorization has to keep up with this rapid growth; otherwise, fossil fuel consumption and its impact will keep rising. Isoprene is an important chemical used mainly in rubber-related and polymer industries [6–8]. Currently, the main production of isoprene is carried out through the naphtha cracking of fossil fuels [6,9]. Consequently, the increase in isoprene demand could contribute to the increase in fossil fuel consumption and its environmental impact. As a class of terpenoids, isoprene can be extracted from plants; however, isoprene production from plants has never been reported as an ideal strategy since the chemical is volatile [10]. A green alternative for isoprene production via microbial strategies has also been reported [10,11]. Nevertheless, several challenges, such as identifying and optimizing the assembly of heterologous genes encoding the member of isoprene-production pathways and finding the optimum conditions for isoprene production, become the main hurdles to the efficient production of isoprene [10]. As a result, the effort to design an efficient strategy for isoprene production is still ongoing. Reasonably, isoprene can be produced via catalytic dehydration of its corresponding diols, i.e., 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol (3MBDO) [7,12–14], since the similar strategy has successfully generated 1,3-butadiene from its corresponding diols, such as 1,3-, 2,3-, and 1,4-butanediol [15–17]. In the dehydration of butanediols to 1,3-butadiene, unsaturated alcohols (UOLs) were generated as intermediate [15–19]. Several catalysts, such as solid acids [18–22] and rare-earth oxides (REO) [23–25], show promising activity in the dehydration of butanediols to 1,3-butadiene via UOLs. In a similar manner, isoprene can be generated from 3MBDO through two consecutive dehydrations. Recently, Bai et at. have reported a promising strategy for the formation of 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol in liquid-phase over Pt-CeOx/Al2O3 catalyst [26]. They also showed that the liquid-phase dehydration of the 2-methyl-1,3-butanediol over several heteropolyacid affords a yield of isoprene of ∼80%, verifying that a non-linear C5 1,3-diols were a promising candidate for isoprene production. This result further signifies the potential for vapor-phase production of isoprene from 3MBDO. Intriguingly, the catalytic dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene is still rarely reported despite the fact that this transformation is a viable and green alternative for isoprene production. Previously, we employed carbon-modified Al2O3 (C/Al2O3) [27] and yttria-stabilized zirconia (Y2Zr2O7) [14] for catalytic dehydration of 3MBDO. As an acid catalyst, the C/Al2O3 catalyzed the dehydration of 3MBDO at a lower reaction temperature than Y2Zr2O7. Nevertheless, the C/Al2O3 catalyst rarely produces isoprene, and the main product is 3-methyl-3-butene-1-ol (3M31), along with a substantial amount of isobutene (IB) as the side product. In contrast, the Y2Zr2O7 catalyst requires a higher reaction temperature for an efficient production of isoprene. At low reaction temperatures, UOLs are generated as the main products with a small yield of isoprene. Under optimum conditions, the isoprene yield exceeds 80% with a small yield of IB. Another main difference in the dehydration of 3MBDO between C/Al2O3 and Y2Zr2O7 catalysts is the reaction mechanism. The 3MBDO dehydration over C/Al2O3 proceeds over acid sites; thus, the acid properties of C/Al2O3 play an essential role in determining the activity and selectivity. On the other hand, the dehydration of 3MBDO over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism, in which both acid and base sites of Y2Zr2O7 influence the catalytic performance. In addition, the crystallinity of the Y2Zr2O7 has a major role in the dehydration of 3MBDO. Therefore, catalyst preparation can also affect the performance of Y2Zr2O7 catalyst. Since REO can generate isoprene efficiently with a low rate of side reaction, catalytic dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene over REO catalyst can be viewed as a promising strategy for efficient isoprene production. Previously, we have reported that ytterbium oxide (Yb2O3) efficiently transforms 1,4-butanediol to 1,3-butadiene, giving a high BD yield and productivity of 97.4% and 34.6 mol kgcat-1 h-1, respectively [25]. The high selectivity to 1,3-butadiene is driven by a low rate of decomposition of 3-buten-1-ol to propylene, which is considered as the main route for the major side product. Referring to this work, Yb2O3 catalyst could potentially be applied for the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene. Similar to the previous work, Yb2O3 catalyst might also have a low rate of decomposition of 3M31, an analogous intermediate to 3-buten-1-ol; thus, boosting the selectivity to isoprene. In this work, Yb2O3, prepared through hydrothermal (HT) process, was employed as a catalyst for the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene. The effect of HT time and calcination temperature was investigated to determine the optimum conditions for preparing a highly active Yb2O3 catalyst. Reaction parameters, such as temperature and contact time, were also analyzed to determine the most conducive conditions for isoprene production. The possible route for isoprene production was investigated using UOLs as the reactant feed. Lastly, the role of acid and base sites of the Yb2O3 was elaborated after the poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine (DMP). The success of this catalytic design might provide a viable alternative for isoprene production, reducing the dependency on naphtha cracking of fossil fuels. 2 Experimentation 2.1 Catalysts preparation Rare earth nitrates such as Sm(NO3)3, Eu(NO3)3, Gd(NO3)3, Tb(NO3)3, Dy(NO3)3, Ho(NO3)3, Y(NO3)3, Er(NO3)3, Tm(NO3)3, Yb(NO3)3, and Lu(NO3)3 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Co., U.S.A. Ytterbium oxide (Yb2O3) catalyst was prepared by HT, according to a previous report [25]. Typically, Yb(NO3)3·5 H2O (4.559 g, 10.15 mmol) was placed into a 100 mL Teflon container and dissolved with 50 mL of distilled water by sonication for 15 min. The resulting solution was stirred while 10 mL of 25 wt% NH3 solution was added dropwisely to form a white slurry. The slurry was continuously stirred for another 10 min, and then it was hydrothermally treated at 200 °C for a specified time. After the HT process was completed, the white precipitate was collected by centrifugation and washed three times using distilled water. The precipitate was dried at 110 °C for 15 h in air to obtain an as-dried sample, which was then calcined in air at a specified temperature for 3 h. The catalyst is denoted as Yb2O3-T, where T represents the calcination temperature. Other REO catalysts were prepared in a similar manner to the procedure described above. Commercially available La2O3, Pr6O11, Nd2O3, and Yb2O3 were purchased from Kanto Chemical Co. Ltd., Japan and CeO2 was supplied by Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co., Ltd., Japan. They were finally calcined at a specified temperature for 3 h. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The specific surface area (SA) was calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed by New D8 ADVANCE (Bruker) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) to identify the crystalline phase of the Yb2O3 catalysts. The thermogravimetry analysis (TG) was performed using Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku). Prior to the measurement, a sample (ca. 10 mg) was heated in the air at 110 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water on the sample. The weight change of the sample was monitored while the sample was heated from 110 to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The acid-base properties of the Yb2O3 catalyst were evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of adsorbed NH3 or CO2 using BELCATII (MicrotracBEL Co.) equipped with a TCD detector: the detail procedure was described in the previous papers [24,28–30]. Prior to the adsorption of NH3 or CO2, the sample was heated in a helium flow at 500 °C for 1 h. The sample was cooled down to 100 °C, then NH3 or CO2 was introduced to the sample at 100 °C for 1 h. Afterward, the desorption of NH3 or CO2 was monitored from 100 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The original TCD signals in TPD profiles are shown in Fig. S1. The presence of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was investigated by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy using an infrared spectrophotometer (IRAffinity-1S, Shimadzu Co., Japan) with pyridine as a probe molecule at a wavenumber ranging from 400 to 4000 cm-1. Prior to measurement, the Yb2O3-900 catalyst was pressed until it became a thin disk and pre-heated at 200 °C under reduced pressure for 1 h. The sample disk was cooled down to 30 °C, and the reference spectrum was collected at 30 °C. Thereafter, pyridine vapor was introduced to the sample at 30 °C for 0.5 h. After sequential evacuation at 30, 50, 80, 100, 150, and 200 °C for 0.5 h, the spectra were recorded at 30 °C. Finally, FT-IR spectra were obtained by subtracting the reference spectrum previously acquired from each acquired spectrum. 2.3 Catalytic test 3MBDO, 2-methyl-3-buten-2-ol (2M32), 3-methyl-2-buten-1-ol (3M21), and 3M31 were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co. and used without purification. The dehydration was carried out under atmospheric pressure in a fixed-bed down flow reactor. A catalyst with a weight, W, ranging from 0.13 – 6.0 g was loaded into the reactor and pre-treated at a reaction temperature (300 – 500 °C) for 1 h in a mixed carrier gas of nitrogen and methane (N2/CH4 = 99) at a flow rate of 30 cm3 min 1. The reactant was fed into the reactor at a flow rate, F, of 1.6 g h-1. The dehydration was carried out for the time on stream (TOS) of 5 or 10 h. The liquid reaction effluents collected every hour were identified using gas chromatography (GC) with mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050, Shimadzu). The reaction products were quantitatively analyzed using a GC equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID-GC, GC-8A, Shimadzu) with a direct injection unit and a 30-m capillary column (Inert Cap WAX-HT, inner diameter of 0.53 mm, GL Sciences) using 1-octanol as an internal standard. Gaseous products were collected by a gastight syringe and the products with isoprene were analyzed by another FID-GC (GC-8A) with a 30-m capillary column (Inert Cap 5 with an inner diameter of 0.53 mm, GL Sciences) using methane in the carrier gas as an internal standard. The conversion of 3MBDO was calculated by the following equation: Conversion % = 1 − 3 MBDO recovered 3 MBDO fed × 100 Product selectivity was calculated by the following equation: Selectivity mol % = mol of specific product in gas and l iquid phase mol of total products × 100 Meanwhile the productivity of isoprene (P isoprene) was determined by using the following equation: P isoprene g g cat − 1 h − 1 = 68.12 × conversion × selectivity 10000 × W / F × 104.15 where 68.12 and 104.15 were the molar mass of isoprene and 3MBDO, respectively. 2.4 Poisoning experiment 2,6-DMP and 3,5-DMP were purchased from Fujifilm Wako Pur Chemical, Co., Japan. The poisoning experiment using 2,6- and 3,5-DMP was conducted in a similar manner to that of catalytic test using a reactant containing 3 mol% of either 2,6- or 3,5-DMP. The CO2 poisoning was performed by introducing CO2 gas at a flow rate of 15 cm3 min-1 into the carrier gas to achieve the total flow rate of 30 cm3 min-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts screening Table 1 summarizes the catalytic performance of several REO catalysts prepared through HT process in the dehydration of 3MBDO at 325 °C and a W/F of 0.125 h, i.e., a weight hourly space velocity, WHSV = 8.0 h-1. CeO2 catalyst, which has been reported to convert diols to their corresponding UOLs efficiently [31], gave the highest conversion of 3MBDO (entry 2). However, negligible isoprene was observed, indicating that the consecutive dehydration of UOLs, i.e., 3M21, 3M31, and 2M32, to isoprene hardly proceeded at 325 °C. Other REO-900 catalysts, such as La2O3, Pr6O11, Nd2O3, Sm2O3, Eu2O3, Gd2O3, Tb4O7, Dy2O3, Ho2O3, Y2O3, Er2O3, and Tm2O3, gave lower catalytic performance than CeO2-900: they had lower 3MBDO conversion and UOLs selectivity (entries 1 and 3 – 13). The UOLs selectivity of Yb2O3-900 and Lu2O3-900 was comparable to that of CeO2-900 (entries 14 and 15). Because Lu2O3 is more expensive than Yb2O3, the utilization of Yb2O3-900 would be preferable to Lu2O3-900. We also tested the activity of a commercially available Yb2O3-900 (entry 16): its performance was lower than the Yb2O3-900 prepared through the HT process although it has a slightly larger SA. Previously, it has been reported that the crystal structure of the majority of REO shown in Table 1 is cubic bixbyite, whereas CeO2 having cubic fluorite structure [25]. The difference in activity between REO catalysts is related to their ionic radius [32–34]. Fig. S2 shows the correlation between REO ionic radius with UOLs formation rate and selectivity. The correlation between UOLs formation rate and ionic radius has been reported in the dehydration of 1,3- [32], 1,4-BDO [25,33] and 1,5-pentanediol [34]. Even though the activity of several REO catalysts varies depending on the type of diols, in general, Yb2O3 and CeO2 always emerge as the potential catalysts in the dehydration of diols. In the dehydration of 3MBDO, the catalysts with the ionic radius close to 0.087 nm gave efficient formation rate of UOLs. Dy2O3 catalyst gave the UOLs formation rate next to Yb2O3 although it had poor selectivity to UOLs and facilitated substantial side reactions. Similarly, Y2Zr2O7, which is reported to act as an efficient catalyst in the dehydration of 3MBDO [14], has also an ionic radius of 0.087 nm. These findings suggest that the crystallite with optimum size is necessary for an efficient catalytic dehydration of 3MBDO. In the case of CeO2 catalyst, the UOLs formation rate is the highest despite the fact that it has a large ionic radius. However, CeO2 catalyst has a crystal structure of cubic fluorite, which is different from the rest of REO tested. In addition, the redox and acid-base properties have been reported to influence the activity of CeO2 [31]; thus, it is reasonable that the optimum ionic radius would be different from that REO with cubic bixbyite structure. It is worth noting that the correlation trend between ionic radius and formation rate of UOLs in the dehydration of 3MBDO is similar to that in the dehydration of 1,3-BDO [16,32]. 3.2 Comparison between CeO2 and Yb2O3 catalysts on the isoprene formation Table 1 suggests that CeO2-900 gave the highest 3MBDO conversion with outstanding UOLs selectivity, followed by Yb2O3-900. Nevertheless, the dehydration of UOLs to isoprene did not proceed efficiently over these catalysts at 325 °C and a W/F of 0.125 h. Fig. 1 shows the effect of calcination temperature on the SA and catalytic activity of CeO2 and Yb2O3 catalysts, while the numerical data are shown in Tables S1 and S2. The increase in calcination temperature decreased the SA of both CeO2 and Yb2O3 catalysts possibly due to the growth of CeO2 and Yb2O3 crystallite size. The CeO2 catalyst showed maximum conversion at the calcination temperature of 800 °C (Fig. 1A). The Yb2O3 catalyst had a slightly different behavior (Fig. 1B). The catalytic activity of Yb2O3 catalyst increased with the increase in calcination temperature up to 900 °C and further increment of calcination temperature to 1000 °C declined the catalytic activity. It has been reported that in the dehydration of butanediols over REO catalysts, the activity was not solely affected by the SA but also by the crystallite size of REO [25,33,35]. The increment of calcination temperature increased the particle size of the CeO2 crystal, which consecutively increase the growth of the (111) plane of CeO2 crystal due to the relative stability of this plane. Concurrently, the growth of (111) plane increase the activity of CeO2 catalyst since the (111) plane provides the active species for the dehydration of butanediol [31]. In this work, similar results were obtained in the dehydration of 3MBDO over CeO2. The calcination temperature from 400 to 800 °C increased the crystallite size of CeO2, which promoted the growth of the active plane in the CeO2 catalyst, increasing the activity of CeO2. Further increment of calcination temperature to 900 °C, however, decreased the SA of CeO2 to the point that it affected the activity of CeO2 in the dehydration of 3MBDO. These findings suggest the importance of optimum calcination temperature to generate a CeO2 catalyst with maximum exposure of (111) plane while still providing optimum SA. In Fig. 1B, the effect of calcination temperature on the catalytic activity of Yb2O3, which has a cubic bixbyite structure, was rather similar to that of CeO2 (Fig. 1A). It can be said that the catalytic activity of Yb2O3 in the dehydration of 3MBDO was also affected by the SA and the crystallinity of the catalyst. The main difference between CeO2 and Yb2O3 catalysts is the surface oxygen-defect sites: in the CeO2 catalyst, the (111) plane containing basically one-oxygen defect sites acts as the active site in the dehydration of butanediol, while the (222) plane of Yb2O3 with four-oxygen defect sites has been reported to be the active sites [25]. Since calcination can affect the growth of CeO2 (111) and Yb2O3 (222) planes, it is reasonable that calcination temperature significantly influenced the activity of the respective catalyst. Table 1 clearly indicates that the CeO2-900 and Yb2O3-900 provide the highest catalytic activity among the tested catalysts. However, isoprene was rarely observed due to a low isoprene formation rate from UOLs at 325 °C and a short W/F of 0.125 h. Thus, it is important to investigate the efficiency of the CeO2 and Yb2O3 for isoprene formation. Fig. 2 illustrates the isoprene selectivity against the 3MBDO conversion over CeO2-800 and Yb2O3-900 catalysts at different temperatures. CeO2-800 was unable to produce isoprene efficiently even at the 3MBDO conversion of 80%: the highest isoprene selectivity was around 11% at a 3MBDO conversion higher than 95%. Even though CeO2-800 efficiently converted 3MBDO to UOLs, it had poor activity in converting UOLs to isoprene due to a high rate of side reactions. This finding was further verified by the following result of the dehydration of 3MBDO at higher temperature and a long W/F. Table 2 shows the comparison of the isoprene formation between Yb2O3-900 and CeO2-800 at 400 °C and a long W/F of 2.5 h. Clearly, the isoprene formation over CeO2-800 was less than that over Yb2O3-900 since CeO2-800 promoted the consecutive hydrogenation of isoprene to form methylbutene isomers. Since Yb2O3-900 produced isoprene efficiently rather than CeO2-800, further investigations were carried out using Yb2O3 catalyst. 3.3 Effect of preparation of Yb2O3 on the catalytic performance in the dehydration of 3MBDO Fig. 3 reveals the effect of HT time on the catalytic activity of the resulting Yb2O3-900 catalysts at 325 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h. The numerical data is shown in Table S3. The Yb2O3-900 catalyst with an HT time of 4 h had the highest catalytic activity. The change in the catalytic activity of Yb2O3-900 with HT time was similar to the change in the SA. Previously, we have reported the effect of HT time on the crystallinity of the as-dried samples [25]. Prior to calcination, the as-dried sample exists as Yb4O(OH)9NO3 phase. Prolonging the HT time from 0 to 4 h improves the Yb4O(OH)9NO3 crystallinity, with no further improvement of the crystallinity upon prolonging the HT time. This finding suggests that the HT time of 4 h might generate the best Yb2O3-900 catalyst since the catalyst originated from a high crystalline Yb4O(OH)9NO3 phase. We have previously reported the effect of HT time on the crystallinity of the Yb2O3-800 samples [25]: After calcination at 900 °C, no significant distinction was observed in the diffraction pattern of the Yb2O3-900 catalysts (Figure not shown). Nevertheless, Fig. 3 clearly suggests that different HT time generated Yb2O3-900 catalysts with different activity. It can be said that crystal growth of high crystalline Yb4O(OH)9NO3 phase during calcination at 900 °C led to the generation of a highly efficient Yb2O3-900 catalyst. Fig. 4 shows the effect of calcination temperature on the activity of the resulting Yb2O3 catalysts at 400 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h, while the numerical data is shown in Table S4. The dehydration of UOLs to isoprene proceeded over the Yb2O3 at 400 °C, whereas such isoprene formation was not observed at 325 °C. Raising the calcination temperature up to 900 °C improved the production of isoprene, and further increment of calcination temperature to 1000 °C decreased the selectivity to isoprene. Concurrently, the decrement of isoprene selectivity was accompanied by the increase in UOLs selectivity. These results indicate that the calcination temperature of 900 °C is the most efficient for Yb2O3 catalyst in the sequential dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs and UOLs to isoprene. It is worth noting that the optimum calcination temperature for Yb2O3 catalyst in the dehydration of 3MBDO differs from that of 1,4-butanediol. This difference might originate from the structural differences between 1,4-butanediol and 3MBDO. Consequently, the crystallite size, which is highly affected by the calcination temperature, for the optimum adsorption of 1,4-butanediol would differ from that of 3MBDO. 3.4 Effect of reaction temperature and contact time, W/F Fig. 5A depicts the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of Yb2O3-900 at a W/F of 0.31 h and the numerical data is summarized in Table S5. Obviously, the raise in reaction temperature increased the average conversion of 3MBDO and the selectivity to isoprene while the selectivity to UOLs decreased. This indicates that the raise in reaction temperature increases the total dehydration rate. It is also worth noting that raising the reaction temperature increases the selectivity to IB, suggesting the rate of side reaction, i.e., decomposition of 3M31, increases. Fig. 5B reveals the effect of contact time, W/F, on the activity of Yb2O3-900 at 375 °C. Meanwhile, the details of numerical data are shown in Table S6. A 3MBDO conversion of 66.5% was attained even at the shortest W/F of 0.08 h and conversion of 3MBDO exceeded 95% at a W/F of 0.24 h or higher. Prolonging the W/F decreased the UOLs selectivity and increased the selectivity to isoprene. However, the increment of selectivity to IB was not observed even at the longest W/F tested. These results indicate that the dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs and UOLs to isoprene were strongly affected by W/F, and that the decomposition of 3M31 to IB was mainly affected by reaction temperature. 3.5 Long run performance of Yb2O3-900 catalyst Fig. 6 shows the performance of the Yb2O3-900 catalyst at a long W/F of 3.75 h under several reaction temperatures for a TOS of 10 h, while Table S7 summarizes the average activity for the first 5 h of TOS. The isoprene yield increased as the reaction temperature increased from 375 to 450 °C, whereas a gradual decrement was observed when the reaction temperature increased from 450 to 500 °C. At 375 °C, a low isoprene yield was driven by the low rate of UOLs dehydration to isoprene, as indicated by the substantial UOLs yield of 14.5% remained (Table S7). On the other hand, at a high temperature of 500 °C, the low isoprene yield was caused by a high rate of 3M31 decomposition to produce IB. Although a reaction temperature of 400 °C or higher gave substantial selectivity to IB at a short W/F of 0.31 h (Table S5), the same phenomenon was not observed when a long W/F of 3.75 h was employed (Fig. 5A). For comparison, at 450 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h, the yield of isoprene and IB were 33.7% and 21.5%, respectively. Meanwhile, the yield of isoprene and IB at 450 °C and a W/F of 3.75 h were 92.1% and 2.4%, respectively. This finding suggests that the formation of isoprene, i.e., dehydration of 3MBDO and UOLs, was substantially more sensitive to the increase in reaction temperature and W/F than the formation of IB via the decomposition of 3M31. Moreover, even though the dehydration of 3M31 to isoprene hardly proceeded at a low reaction temperature and a short W/F, this process proceeds more smoothly at a high temperature and a long W/F. As a result, the formation of IB was suppressed since 3M31 was majorly converted to isoprene. Figs. 5 and 6 have shown that isoprene production is affected by reaction temperature and W/F. It is also worth noting that performing the experiment at a long W/F is highly beneficial for isoprene production; nevertheless, prolonging W/F, i.e., the weight of Yb2O3-900 catalyst, can affect the P isoprene. Fig. S3 shows the correlation of reaction temperature and W/F with P isoprene. Even though high P isoprene could be achieved at short W/F (Fig. S3A), it was achieved at the expense of the selectivity to isoprene. On the other hand, prolonging W/F promoted high selectivity to isoprene, but this led to a decrease in P isoprene (Fig. S3B and S3C). In this report, the highest P isoprene of 0.711 g gca t -1 h-1 was achieved at 450 °C and W/F of 0.31 h, with isoprene selectivity of 33.7%. Meanwhile, the highest yield of isoprene of 92.7% was obtained at 450 °C and a long W/F of 3.75 h, with P isoprene of 0.16 g gcat -1 h-1. For reference, the dehydration of 3MBDO over Y2Zr2O7 gave isoprene yield and productivity of 82.4% and 0.29 g gcat -1 h-1 [25]. The Y2Zr2O7 catalyst gave a lower selectivity to isoprene due to a slightly higher rate of IB formation, even at a lower reaction temperature of 375 °C. This phenomenon is reasonable since Y2Zr2O7 contains more acid sites than Yb2O3. The promotion of the 3M31 decomposition to IB by the acid site is also found in the dehydration of 3MBDO over the C/Al2O3 catalyst [25]. Although the dehydration of 3MBDO is carried out at a low temperature of 200 °C, substantial IB was observed along with 3M31 as the major product. Fig. 7 shows the TG profiles of catalysts used in the reaction shown in Fig. 6. The highest coke accumulated was observed after the Yb2O3-900, with a SA of 11.6 m2 g-1, had been used at a reaction temperature of 500 °C. Nevertheless, the amount of coke was less than 2%. The least coke deposited on Yb2O3-900 occurred at a reaction temperature of 450 °C, which provides the highest activity and stability. 3.6 Reaction route to isoprene in the dehydration of 3MBDO In the dehydration of 3MBDO, isoprene is produced via two consecutive dehydrations, i.e., dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs followed by the dehydration of UOLs to isoprene. At a low reaction temperature and a short W/F, the dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs proceeded together with negligible formation of isoprene, as depicted in Figs. 1 and 3. In the dehydration of 3MBDO, 2M32 was generated as the dominant UOL compared to 3M21 and 3M31, regardless of reaction conditions (Tables S1–S6). In contrast, substantial consumption of 3M21 and 3M31 was observed at a high temperature or at a long W/F (Tables S4–S7). Thus, each UOL might have different reactivity. Table 3 shows the dehydration reactivity of three UOLs over the Yb2O3-900 at 375 °C and a W/F of 0.26 h. Although the dehydration of 2M32 generated isoprene with a high selectivity of 77.8%, the 2M32 conversion was only 3% (entry 1). On the other hand, the dehydration of 3M21 and 3M31 gave a substantially higher conversion (entries 2 and 3) than the dehydration of 2M32, suggesting that 3M21 and 3M31 were more reactive than 2M32. According to these findings, the high selectivity to 2M32 in comparison with the other UOLs was due to its relative stability, i.e. poor reactivity. Among the UOLs employed, 3M21 was converted mainly to isoprene, with minor production of 2M32 and 3M31 via the isomerization of 3M21 (entry 2). Meanwhile, 3M31 was competitively converted to isoprene, 3M21, and IB, where the selectivity to 3M21 and IB was nearly identical (entry 3). This suggests that the rate of isomerization and decomposition of 3M31 was rather similar. Compared to the other UOLs, 3M31 generated IB with the highest selectivity, indicating that 3M31 was the major source of IB in the dehydration of 3MBDO. This observation is basically identical to the previous report on the dehydration of 3MBDO over Y2Zr2O7 catalyst [14]. This assumption was further supported by the finding in Fig. 6, which clearly suggests that the increment of dehydration rate of 3M31 to isoprene reduces the formation of IB substantially. In general, 3M21 was the primary source for isoprene production, while 3M31 generated isoprene via direct dehydration or via stepwise reaction through isomerization to 3M21. 2M32 was also dehydrated to isoprene with a lower rate than 3M21 and 3M31 ( Scheme 1). 3.7 Roles of acid and base sites of Yb2O3-900 catalyst Previous reports have suggested that the dehydration of 1,3-, 2,3-, 1,4-butanediol, and 3MBDO over REO proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism [14,32,36,37], indicating the importance of an acid-base pair site of REO. Initially, the presence of acid and base sites on Yb2O3-900 was investigated by NH3- and CO2-TPD analyses. Fig. 8A displays the NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles of Yb2O3-900. The NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles barely gave any signal associated with the presence of acid and base sites. The total amount of NH3- and CO2-uptake were only 9 and 12 μmol g–1, respectively, indicating that Yb2O3-900 only contained a small amount of acid and base sites. The small amount of acid and base concentration is possibly due to the small SA of Yb2O3-900. Although the NH3- and CO2-TPD hardly gave insight into the acid and base properties of Yb2O3-900, the FT-IR spectra of the adsorbed pyridine clearly suggest that Yb2O3-900 contains Lewis acid site (Fig. 8B). The bands at 1440 cm-1 and 1610 cm-1 are assigned to as the pyridine adsorbed on the Lewis acid site [38,39]. Even though the band at 1490 cm-1 has been reported as the evidence for the presence of Lewis and Brønsted acid site [40,41], the absence of any band associated with pure pyridinium ion on Bronsted acid at 1540 cm-1, suggests that the band around 1490 cm-1 solely corresponds to Lewis acid site. Notably, the bands associated with the Lewis acid sites remained even after evacuation at 200 °C, indicating the presence of strong Lewis acid sites. The static characterization of FT-IR of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. 8B) revealed the presence of Lewis acid sites. There is still unclear issue of base sites although the basicity is larger than the acidity in the TPD results of Fig. 8A. We further characterize the acid-base property of Yb2O3-900 in a dynamic state using poisons during the dehydration of 3MBDO: 2,6- and 3,5-DMP were used to investigate the role of acid sites and CO2 gas was used to clarify the role of base sites. Fig. 9 shows the change in activity of Yb2O3-900 with TOS in the dehydration of 3MBDO at 325 °C and a W/F of 0.31 h in the presence of a poison, while Table S8 lists the details of the product distribution. 2,6-DMP, which has been reported to block only Brønsted acid sites [42], slightly decreased the activity of Yb2O3-900, while 3,5-DMP, which blocks both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [30,42], decreased the performance of Yb2O3-900 substantially. These findings clearly suggest that the UOLs formation in the dehydration of 3MBDO over Yb2O3-900 is induced by Lewis acid sites, not by Brønsted acid sites. This result further confirms the fact that Yb2O3-900 does not contain Brønsted acid sites. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of Yb2O3-900 was suppressed more severely when CO2, which blocks the base site of Yb2O3-900, was flowed with the carrier gas. These results signify the importance of Lewis acid and base sites in the dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs. Fig. 10 depicts the change in activity of Yb2O3-900 with TOS in the dehydration of 3M21 at 375 °C and a W/F 0.26 h, while Table S9 displays the details of the average activity. Because the dehydration of UOLs requires a higher reaction temperature than the dehydration of 3MBDO, the poisoning experiment was carried out at a high temperature of 375 °C (Fig. 10). Similar to the dehydration of 3MBDO, 3,5-DMP decreased the conversion of 3M21 substantially, but 2,6-DMP did not significantly decrease the conversion (Fig. 10A). Nevertheless, the isoprene selectivity was highly affected by the presence of 2,6-DMP (Fig. 10B). It is suggested that Lewis acid sites highly affects the activity of Yb2O3-900. Table S9 clearly shows that the decrement of isoprene selectivity was accompanied by the increment of the selectivity to 3M31, which was converted to 4-methyl-2,3-dihydrofuran. In addition, the poisoning of the base sites by CO2 gas also declined the performance of Yb2O3-900; thus, the base sites were also essential in the dehydration of 3M21. In fact, the overall dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene was hindered in the presence of CO2 gas at 375 °C ( Fig. 11 and Table S10): both the conversion and the isoprene selectivity decreased, which further confirmed that the poisoning effect still proceeded at a temperature where isoprene was generated. However, 2,6- and 3,5-DMP did not poison the dehydration of 3MBDO at 375 °C, as the conversion of 3MBDO did not change with the addition of these DMPs. These findings strongly imply that the dehydration of 3MBDO to UOLs and the consecutive dehydration of UOLs, i.e., 3M21, proceeded over Lewis acid sites and base sites of Yb2O3-900 via acid-base concerted mechanism. Previously, we have proposed a possible mechanism for the dehydration of 1,4-butanediol over Yb2O3 [25]. The (222) plane of cubic bixbyite of Yb2O3 regularly exposes the Yb3+ cation, which is a Lewis acid, due to the oxygen vacancies. These oxygen vacancies provide the adsorption site for 1,4-butanediol. Because the vacancies occupy 1/4 of the surface oxygen, the remaining oxygen anions around the vacancy act as the base site in the dehydration of 1,4-butanediol. We speculate that the dehydration of 3MBDO possibly proceeds in a similar manner to that of 1,4-butanediol [25], as illustrated in Scheme 2. The OH groups of 3MBDO were anchored onto Lewis acid sites of Yb3+ cations. This adsorption allows the abstraction of the position-2 hydrogen by a basic oxygen anion and the position-1 or position-3 OH group by Yb3+ to generate 2M32, 3M21, or 3M31. The consecutive dehydration of UOLs, especially 3M21, proceeds through the interaction with only one OH group. Thus, it is reasonable that the adsorption of UOLs was weaker than that of 3MBDO. Consequently, the rate of UOLs dehydration is lower than the rate of 3MBDO dehydration, and higher reaction temperatures are required for the dehydration of UOLs. In the dehydration of 3M21 over Yb2O3-900, the OH group was adsorbed on the Lewis acid of Yb3+. Because saturated alcohols are less reactive than UOLs over Y2Zr2O7 [13], it is reasonable that C=C bond of 3M21 interacts with the Lewis acid sites of Yb2O3, an adsorption structure illustrated in Scheme 3 can be allowed. The OH group and C=C bond of 3M21 are coordinated to Lewis acid sites of Yb3+ cations and the position-4 hydrogen is abstracted by a basic oxygen anion to produce isoprene (Scheme 3). The dehydration of 3M31 proceeds in a similar manner to 3M21 while the decomposition of 3M31 to IB is also allowed in the coordination shown in the bottom of Scheme 3. 4 Conclusion Yb2O3 prepared via HT protocol acted as an efficient catalyst for the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene. The HT time and the calcination temperature affected the SA and crystallinity of the Yb2O3, which consecutively influenced the performance of Yb2O3. The reaction temperature and W/F significantly influence the dehydration of 3MBDO and UOLs, while the decomposition of 3M31 to IB, which reduced the selectivity to isoprene, was mainly affected by the reaction temperature. The highest isoprene yield of 92% was achieved at 450 °C and a W/F of 3.75 h. Among UOLs generated, 3M21 was majorly converted to isoprene, while 2M32 was selectively converted to isoprene at a lower rate. In contrast, 3M31 could be converted directly to isoprene or indirectly via isomerization to 3M21. The poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-DMP suggests the importance of base and acid sites in the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene, and that the dehydration of 3MBDO over Yb2O3-900 catalyst proceeds via an acid-base concerted mechanism. coredata.dc:description: Several rare-earth oxides, prepared through a hydrothermal process, were employed as catalysts for vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol (3MBDO) to isoprene. Ytterbium oxide (Yb2O3) emerged as the most efficient catalyst for the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene. The hydrothermal time and calcination temperature influenced the performance of Yb2O3. The reaction temperature and contact time strongly affect the dehydration of 3MBDO and unsaturated alcohols, while the major side reaction of isobutene formation via decomposition of 3-methyl-3-butene-1-ol was mainly influenced by the reaction temperature. The highest isoprene yield of 92% was achieved at 450 °C and a long contact time of 3.75 h. The poisoning experiment using CO2, 2,6-, and 3,5-dimethylpyridine revealed the importance of base and acid sites of Yb2O3 in the dehydration of 3MBDO, indicating the dehydration of 3MBDO to isoprene proceeded via an acid-base concerted mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrothermally fabricated Yb2O3 catalyst for vapor-phase dehydration of 3-methyl-1,3-butanediol to isoprene
